titleStmt.title: The city of London's plea to the Quo warranto, (an information) brought against their Charter in Michaelmas term, 1681 wherein it will appear, that the liberties, priviledges, and customs of the said city cannot be forfeited, or lost by the misdemeanor of any officer or magistrate thereof, nor their Charter be seized into the King's hands for any mis-usage or abusage of their liberties and priviledges, they being confirmed by divers ancient records and acts of Parliament made before and since Magna Charta : also, how far the Commons of the said city have power of chusing and removing their sheriffs / published both in English and Latin.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: In Engli≈øh thus: The Information in Michaelmas Term, in the Thirty Third Year of Car. II. King of England, &c.
div.p:
Lond. ≈ø≈ø. MEmorand' That Robert Sawyer Knight, our Lord the Kings Attorney General, who on this behalf pro≈øecutes for our ≈øaid Lord the King, appears here in his own per≈øon in the Court of our ≈øaid Lord the King, before the King him≈øelf at We≈øtmin≈øter on Munday next after the Quindene of St. Martin (viz. Nov. 27.) in the ≈øame Term; and for our ≈øaid Lord the King, gives this Court to under≈øtand and be informed, That the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, for the ≈øpace of one month la≈øt pa≈øt, and longer, have u≈øed, and do yet u≈øe, and claim to have and u≈øe (without any Warrant or Royal Grant) within the City of London afore≈øaid, and the Liberties and Precincts of the ≈øaid City, divers Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchi≈øes following, to wit, To be of them≈øelves one Body Corporate and Politick, in the Name of the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by the ≈øame Name to implead and be impleaded, to an≈øwer and be an≈øwered; And al≈øo to have a Sheriff of the City and County of the City of London, and to Nominate and Elect out of them≈øelves two per≈øons, One to be the Sheriff of the City afore≈øaid, and of the County of the ≈øame City, and him ≈øo nominated and elected to prefer and con≈øtitute Sheriff of the City afore≈øaid and of the County of the ≈øaid City, for the Execution and Return of all Breve's, Bills, and Precepts of our Lord the King, for the admini≈øtration and execution of the Ju≈øtice within the City
afore≈øaid, and County of the ≈øame City, to be executed and done, and to do and execute all and every the other things within the City afore≈øaid, and County of the ≈øame, that belong to the Office of a Sheriff: And al≈øo to Nominate, Elect and Con≈øtitute Another per≈øon out of them≈øelves for the Sheriff of the County of Middle≈øex, for the ≈øaid County to ≈øerve as Sheriff for the ≈øame, and to execute there and make return of all Breve's, Bills and Precepts of our Lord the King within the County of Middle≈øex afore≈øaid, for the admini≈øtration and execution of Ju≈øtice, without any Commi≈ø≈øion or Letters Patents obtained or to be obtained from our Lord the King on that behalf: And al≈øo, that the Mayor and Aldermen of the ≈øaid City, have been Ju≈øtices of our Lord the King to keep the Peace within the ≈øaid City, and to hold Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace and Pleas of the Crown within the ≈øaid City, and all the Felonies, Riots and unlawful Conventicles within the ≈øaid City, to enquire into, hear and determine by their own proper authority, without any Commi≈ømi≈ø≈øion or other Authority from our Lord the King granted or obtained on that behalf. All and every of which Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchi≈øes, the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, for all the ≈øaid time, have u≈øurped, and do ≈øtill u≈øurp over our ≈øaid Lord the King, to the contempt of our ≈øaid Lord the King, and to the great damage and prejudice of his Prerogative Royal. Whereupon the ≈øaid Attorney-General of our Lord the King, doth de≈øire for our ≈øaid Lord the King the Advice of this Court in the premi≈ø≈øes, and due cour≈øe of Law to be made again≈øt the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid on this behalf, to an≈øwer our ≈øaid Lord the King, By what Warrant they claim to have, u≈øe and enjoy the Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchi≈øes afore≈øaid, &c.

utlagarent' faciend' & continuand' & ad omnia & ≈øingula murdra fellon' vene≈øic' incantat' ≈øcortileg' Artis magic' tam fal≈øas Con≈øpiration' & al' malefact' fore≈øtall' regrat' ingro≈ø≈øar' Extortion' Conventicul' Indictament' pred' ceteraque omnia & ≈øingula premi≈øs' ≈øecund' Leges & Statut' Regni ≈øui Angl' prout in huju≈ømodi Ca≈øu fieri con≈øuevit aut debuit audiend' & terminand' & ad ca≈ødem delinquen' & quamlibet eoru' pro debit' ≈øuis per fines redemption' amerciament' forisfactur' & al' modo prout ≈øecundum Legem & Con≈øuetud' Regni ≈øui Angl' ac formam Ordination' & Statut' corundem fieri con≈øuevit aut debuit ca≈øtigand' & puniend' ac ad omnia al' & ≈øingula faciend' exercend' audiend' terminand' & exequend' infra Civit' praed' ac Libertat' eju≈ødem quae Ju≈øtic' ad pacem per Leges vel per Statut' hujus Regni ≈øui Angl' facere exercere inquirere vel exequi po≈ø≈øent & valerent & in tam amplis' modo & forma prout aliquis' al' aut aliqui al' Ju≈øtic' ad Pacem in aliquibus al' Com' hujus' regni ≈øui Angel' ligittime facere exercere inquirere punire vel quoque modo exequi po≈ø≈øent aut valerent' prout per ea≈ødem Litteras Patent' inter al' plenius apparet Quodque predictus Domin' Rex nunc per Litteras ≈øuas Patent' ≈øub Magno Sigillo ≈øuo Angl' Sigillat' geren' dat' apud We≈øtm' predict' vice≈øimo quarto die Junii Anno Regni ≈øui decimo quinto quas iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit' London hic
in Cur' proferunt omnes Conce≈ø≈øion' & al' quecunque in predict' Litteris Patent' predict' nuper Regis Caroli Primi Superius ≈øpecificat' pro eodem Domin' Regis nunc Hered' & Succe≈ø≈øor' ≈øuis Majori & Communitat' ac Civibus Civit' London pred' & coru' Succe≈ø≈øor' in perpetuu' ratificavit & confirmavit prout per ea≈ødem Litteras Patent' ip≈øius Domin' Regis nunc inter al' plenius apparet & iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit' London Ulterius dicunt quod tempore confection' predict' Litterar' Patent' pred' nuper Regis Caroli Primi & dum antea & extunc hucu≈øque fuer' & adhuc exi≈øtunt Major' & Recordator' Civit' pred' ac Alderman' eju≈ødem Civit'. qui Major dicte Civit' extiti≈ø≈øent & onus Majorat' Civit' illius ≈øu≈øtin' ac tres & plures! Alderman' eju≈ødem Civit' qui onus Majorat' Civit' ill' non ≈øu≈øtinui≈ø≈øent Quodque a tempore confection' eorundem Litterar' Patent' predict' nuper Regis Caroli Primi hucu≈øque Major & Recordator Civit' pred' pro tempore exi≈øtend ac huju≈ømodi Alderman' eju≈ødem Civitat' pro tempore exi≈øten' qui onus Majorat' Civit' ill' ≈øu≈øtin' Necnon tres Senior' Alderman' Civit' predict' pro tempore exi≈øten' qui diutius in Officiu' Aldermannat' Civit' pred' ≈øteter', & onus & Officit' Majorat' Civit' ill' non ≈øu≈øtin' virtute Litterar' Patent' ill' fuer' Ju≈øtic' ad pacem infra Civit' pred' & libertat' eju≈ødem con≈øervand' ac virtute Litterar' Patent' ill' & ≈øecundum formam & effectu' eorund' de tempore in tempus per tot' tempus ill' tener' Se≈ø≈øion' pacis & placita coron' ≈øcilicet talia placita coron' qual' Ju≈øtic' Domin' Regis ad pacem con≈øervand'
a≈ø≈øign' per idem tempus ligittime tener' vel tenere potueri inf' eandem Civitat'.

Et eo Warranto iidem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit' London per tempus in Informatione praed' ≈øuperius ≈øpecificat' u≈øi fuer' & adhuc utuntur ac clamant habere & uti Libertat' Privileg' & Franch' quod Major dict' Civit' & huju≈ømodi Aldermann' eju≈ødem Civit' qui onus Majorat' Civit' ill' ≈øu≈øtinner' ac inde fuerunt dimi≈ø≈øi ac tres ≈øeniores Aldermann' eju≈ødem Civit' qui diutius Offic' Aldermannat' Ci, vit praedict' ≈øteter' & onus & Officiu' Majorat' Civit' ill' non ≈øu≈øtuler' fuer' Ju≈øtic' Domin' Regis ad Pacem infra Civit' praedict' con≈øervand' ac ad Se≈ø≈øion' Pacis & Placita Corone (≈øcilicet) talia Placita Coron' qual' Ju≈øtic' Domin' Regis ad Pacem con≈øervand' a≈ø≈øign' ligittime tenere po≈ø≈øent infra eand' Civit' tenend' ac ad omnes Felon' Riot' Rout' & Conventicul' illicit' infra Civit' praed' inquirend' audiend' & terminand' prout eis bene licuit & licet.

Ab≈øque hoc quod idem Major & Communitas ac Cives Civit' London de Libertat' Privileg' & Franches ill' ≈øuper dictum Domin' Regem nunc per tempus praed' in Informatione praed' ≈øuperius ≈øpecificat' u≈øurpaver' ≈øeu u≈øurpant pro ut per Inform' illam pro dicto Dom' Rege nunc ≈øuperius ≈øupponit' Quae omn' & ≈øingula iidem Major & Communitas & Cives Civit' London perati ≈øunt verificare unde petunt Judicium & quod Libertat' Privileg' & Franch' illis eis & Succe≈ø≈øoribus ≈øuis in perpetuum deinceps allocentur & adjudicent' ac
quod ip≈øi quoad premi≈ø≈øa illi ab hac Curia dimittantur, &c.

Et quoad re≈øid' Libertat' Privileg' & Franchi≈øa in Information' praedict' ≈øpecificat' per i≈øum Majorem & Communitat' ac Cives Civitat' London ≈øuperimo nomine clamat iidem Major & Communit' ac Cives Civit' London Libertat' Privileg' & Franchi≈øa illis nunquam u≈øi fuerunt ≈øeu utuntur ≈øed de ei≈ødem penitus declamans, &c.

div.head: The Mayor Commonalty and Citizens of London at the Suit of the King.
div.p:
ANd the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, by Bendict Brown their Attorney, came and had Hearing of the Information afore≈øaid, by colour of which Information they are Pro≈øecuted and may be hereafter burthened vexed and di≈øquieted, and that unju≈øtly, becau≈øe by Prote≈øtation that in the ≈øaid Information there is nothing contain'd material or ≈øufficient in the Law, to which Information they have no nece≈ø≈øity, nor by the Law of the Land they ought to be held in any manner to An≈øwer neverthele≈øs for Plea; for as much as the Liberties, Priviledges and Franchizes following, viz. They the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London to be of them≈øelves one Body Corporate and Politick in matter fact and name, by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by that Name to Plead and be Impleaded, to An≈øwer, and be An≈øwered in the Information above ≈øpecified, the ≈øaid Mayor Comonalty and Citizens of the City of London ≈øay, That our ≈øaid Soveraign Lord the King that now is, ought not by occa≈øion thereof to Impeach or undoe them, becau≈øe he ≈øaith, That the ≈øaid City of London is, and from which time beyond the memory of Man was an Ancient City; and that the Citizens of the ≈øaid City are, and from that time out of
mind were one Body Corporate and Politick in Matter, Fact, and Name, by the name of Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by that Name during that time have Pleaded, and were Impleaded; have An≈øwered, and were An≈øwered, and to Plead and be Impleaded, to An≈øwer and be An≈øwered, and during the time afore≈øaid have been u≈øed and accu≈øtomed. And that in the Great Charter of the Liberties of England in the Parliament of our Soveraign Lord Henry the Third ≈øometime King of England, at We≈øtmin≈øter in the County of Middle≈øex, in the Ninth Year of his Reign, held, made and provided it is contained, That the Citizens of London ≈øhould have all their ancient Liberties and Cu≈øtoms; And the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty & Citizens of the City of London further ≈øay, That the Lord Edward the Third ≈øometimes King of England, in his Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter in the County of Middle≈øex, in the Fir≈øt Year of his Reign held, by which his Charter, with the con≈øent of the Prelates, Earls Barons and the whole Commonalty of his Realm in his ≈øaid Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid were A≈ø≈øembled. And by the Authority of the ≈øaid Parliament was then Confirmed to the Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, the Liberties following (among≈øt other things) to hold to them≈øelves and their Succe≈ø≈øors for Ever, fir≈øt of all in reciting: That whereas in the Great Charter of the Liberties of England it is contained, That the City of London ≈øhould have all their ancient Liberties and Cu≈øtoms; And that the ≈øaid Citizens, at the time of making the ≈øaid Charter, and in the times of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, and of William the Conquerour and other Progenitors of the ≈øaid King Edward in diver≈øe
Liberties and Cu≈øtoms have had not only by the Charters of their Progenitors, but al≈øo of other Charters of ancient cu≈øtom, the ≈øaid King Edward the Third did give and grant for him≈øelf and his Heirs by tho≈øe Charters, by the Authority afore≈øaid, that the ≈øaid Citizens ≈øhall have their Liberties according to the form of the Great Charter afore≈øaid; And that for any per≈øonal Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion or per≈øonal Judgment of any Officer of the ≈øaid City, the Liberty of that City ≈øhall not be taken into the hands of King Edward the Third or his Succe≈ø≈øors, but ≈øuch Officer for ≈øuch Offence ≈øhall be required and puni≈øhed, as by the ≈øaid Charter, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, the ≈øixth day of March, in the fir≈øt Year of the Reign of the ≈øaid King Edward the Fir≈øt under his Great Seal of England, brought here in Court, among other things more fully doth appear. And the ≈øaid Mayor, Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London further ≈øay, That at the in≈øtance (and at the reque≈øt of the Commonalty of the Realm of England) in the Parliament of our ≈øaid Lord Richard the Second, late King of England, after the Conque≈øt, at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, in the ≈øeventh Year of his Reign, held and a≈ø≈øembled for the greater quiet and peace among the Subjects of the late King, and for the publick good, all Cu≈øtoms, Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchi≈øes of the ≈øaid City then to the Citizens of that City and their Succe≈ø≈øors, although they have not been u≈øed or abu≈øed, have been ratified and confirmed by the Authority of the ≈øaid Parliament. And that our Lord Henry the Sixth, late King of England, by his Letters Patents, ≈øealed with his Great Seal of England, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, the ≈øixth day of
October, in the Twenty third Year of his Reign, which the ≈øaid Mayor, Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court for their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, did confirm to the Mayor and Commonalty, and to the Citizens of the City of London and their Succe≈ø≈øors, all and ≈øingular their Liberties, Franchizes, and free Cu≈øtoms, ≈øo whole and untouched in any time of the Progenitors of the late King Henry the Sixth, when as more freely and better they had the ≈øame, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents, among other things more fully appears. And that our Lord Edward the Fourth, late King of England, by his Letters Patents, under his Great Seal of England, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, the Ninth day of November, in the Second Year of his Reign, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court, for them≈øelves and their Heirs, did confirm to the Mayor and Commonalty and to the Citizens of the City of London and their Succe≈ø≈øors for ever, all and ≈øingular their Liberties, Franchizes and free Cu≈øtoms, ≈øo whole and untouched, like as to them in any time of the Progenitors of the ≈øaid late King Edward the Fourth, they have had and held more quiet and free. And further, the ≈øaid late King Edward the Fourth, by his Letters Patents, did grant to the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and to the Citizens, that although they or their Predece≈ø≈øors, or the Mayor and Aldermen of the ≈øaid City or their Predece≈ø≈øors before or ≈øucceeding then from thence after any or to any Liberties, did quietly grant the Order of Articles or free Cu≈øtoms, or of any other in the ≈øaid Letters
Patents of the ≈øaid late King Edward the Fourth, or other his Letters Patents contained, or of his Progenitors ≈øometime Kings of England to the Mayor and Commonalty, did grant in any Ca≈øe ari≈øing, albeit, they have not been fully u≈øed or abu≈øed: Notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid King Edward the Fourth was unwilling that for this, they the Mayor and Commonalty Aldermen, and Citizens, or their Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhould incur the forfeiture of the Premi≈øes; but that they and their Succe≈ø≈øors all and ≈øingular the Liberties, Freedoms, Grants, Ordinations in the Articles, free-Cu≈øtoms, and what≈øoever el≈øe in the Charters and Letters afore≈øaid contained the like not u≈øed, or al≈øo abu≈øed, and every of them from thence of the re≈øt fully and freely may u≈øe and enjoy without the Impeachment or Impediment of the ≈øaid late King, or his Heirs of the Ju≈øtices, E≈øcheators, Sheriffs any other Bayliff or Officer of the ≈øaid late King, or any other what≈øoever, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents of the ≈øaid late King Edward the Fourth, brought here in Court; among other things more fully appeared. And that the late King Henry the Seventh by his Letters Patents under his Great Seal of England bearing Date at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, the 23d. Day of July, in the 20th. Year of his Reign, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court for them≈øelves their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors did ratifie and confirm to the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London and their Succe≈ø≈øors all and ≈øingular the Liberties, Priviledges, Freedoms and Free Cu≈øtoms, which they the ≈øaid Mayor, Commonalty and Citizens, or their Predece≈ø≈øors have been accu≈øtomed to have, exerci≈øe or enjoy, or have been u≈øed or
accu≈øtomed ≈øo fully, plainly, and wholly, as if all and ≈øingular the ≈øeveral words in the ≈øaid Letters Patents were and have been expre≈ø≈øed, declared, and manife≈øted, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents among other things more fully appears. And the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London further ≈øays, That the late King James by his Letters Patents under his Great Seal of England, bearing Date at his Honour of Hampton-Court the 24th. day of September in the 6th. Year of his Reign which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court by reciting that whereas many others of his Predece≈ø≈øors ≈øometime Kings of England of his ≈øpecial Grace for the many acceptable, laudable, and continued Services by the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London and their Predece≈ø≈øors in times pa≈øt done, and unrewarded; al≈øo for divers other urgent Cau≈øes and con≈øiderations, them ≈øeverally moving did give grant and confirm to the Mayor and Commonalty and to the Citizens of the City of London and their Succe≈ø≈øors divers Liberties Priviledges, Franchizes, Immunities, Authorities, Juri≈ødictions, Ordinances, Cu≈øtoms and Freedoms; as by the ≈øeveral Letters Patents of the Progenitors and Predece≈ø≈øors of the ≈øaid late Kings of England more fully and manife≈øt it doth, and may appear. The ≈øaid King James for, and in con≈øideration of the great Fidelity, Con≈øtancy, and very late and laudable Service by the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, to the late King of this Realm in his fir≈øt coming to this Realm, and continuing until then manife≈øted and mo≈øt faithfully done and unrewarded all and ≈øingular Letters Patents Charters,
and Confirmations of his mo≈øt noble Progenitors and Predece≈ø≈øors to the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid and their Succe≈ø≈øors, by what name ≈øoever incorporated, before that time made, granted or confirmed, and all and ≈øingular Donations, Grants, Confirmations, Re≈øtitutions, Cu≈øtoms, Ordinances, Explanations, Articles, and all other things what≈øoever in what≈øoever Letters Patents or Charters what≈øoever of the Progenitors, Predece≈ø≈øors or Ance≈øtors of the ≈øaid Kings of England; al≈øo all and ≈øingular in the ≈øaid Letters Patents, Charters, Conce≈ø≈øions, Confirmations, or any of them contained, recited, ≈øpecified, confirmed, or explained. And all and ≈øingular Juri≈ødictions, Authorities, Priviledges, Liberties, Franchizes, Freedoms, Immunities, free Cu≈øtoms, and Hereditaments what≈øoever, which the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London or their Predece≈ø≈øors, by the Name of the Mayor and Commonalty and of the Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of London, or by the Name of the Mayor, Citizens and Commonalty of the City of London or by the Name of Mayor and Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of the Mayor and Commonalty of the City of London, or by the Name of the Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of Barons of London, or by the Name of Barons of the City of London, or by any other Name what≈øoever, by rea≈øon or force of any Letters Patents, Charters or Con≈øirmations of any the Progenitors, Predece≈ø≈øors or Ance≈øtors of the ≈øaid late King James, in any time or times have been had or rea≈øonably
been u≈øed or exerci≈øed, or have been adjudged for them≈øelves and their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, did accept and approve, and all and ≈øingular to the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and to the Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, and their Succe≈ø≈øors, by the ≈øaid Letters Patents did ratifie and confirm to have, hold, enjoy, and exerci≈øe, all and ≈øingular the Premi≈ø≈øes to the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and to the Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, and their Succe≈ø≈øors for ever, ≈øo fully, freely, and wholly, as in as large manner and form as if every ≈øeveral ≈øingle Name, and Name by Name, in tho≈øe ≈øaid Letters Patents have been expre≈ø≈øed, named, declared, recited, and manife≈øted, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents, among other things, more fully appears. And that the ≈øaid late King Charles the Fir≈øt by his Letters Patents, under his Great Seal of England, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter afore≈øaid, the Eighteenth day of October, in the Fourteenth Year of his Reign, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court, all and ≈øingular Priviledges, Liberties, Franchizes, Freedoms, Immunities and free Cu≈øtoms what≈øoever, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, or their Predece≈ø≈øors, by the Name of the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of the Mayor and Aldermen, Citizens and Commonalty of London, or by the Name of Mayor and Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty of the City of London, or by the Name of the Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of the Barons of London, or by the Name
of the Barons of the City of London, or by any other Name what≈øoever, by rea≈øon or force of the ≈øaid Letters Patents, Charters or Confirmations in the ≈øaid Letters Patents of the ≈øaid late King Charles the Fir≈øt mentioned, or in u≈øe or by pre≈øcription, or in any other lawful manner, in any time or in any time or times before that time have had or have been rea≈øonably u≈øed or exerci≈øed, declared and adjudged for them≈øelves, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, did accept and approve, and all and ≈øingular to the afore≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London and their Succe≈ø≈øors, by their ≈øaid Letters Patents have ratified and confirmed, as by tho≈øe ≈øaid Letters Patents (among other things) it doth and may appear. And that our Lord the King that now is, by his Letters Patents, under his Great Seal of England, bearing date at We≈øtmin≈øter, the Twenty fourth day of June, in the Fifteenth Year of his Reign, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London brings here in Court for the ≈øaid King him≈øelf, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, did ratifie and confirm to the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, their Succe≈ø≈øors, all and ≈øingular the Juri≈ødictions, Authorities, Priviledges, Liberties, Franchizes, Freedoms, Immunities, and Cu≈øtoms what≈øoever, which the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London or their Predece≈ø≈øors by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of Mayor, Aldermen, Citizens and Commonalty of London, or by the Name of Mayor and Citizens of the City of London, or by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty of the City of London,
or by the Name of the Citizens of the City of London; or by the Name of the Barons of London, or by the Name of the Barons of the City of London, or by any other Name what≈øoever, by rea≈øon or force of the Letters Patents Charters or Confirmations in the ≈øaid Letters Patents of our ≈øaid now Lord the King before mention'd, or of any or any u≈øe or u≈øes, pre≈øcription or pre≈øcriptions, or in any other Legal way what≈øoever in any time or times before then, have been had, or rea≈øonably have been u≈øed or exerci≈øed to have, hold, enjoy and exerci≈øe all and ≈øingular the ≈øaid Premi≈øes to the Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London afore≈øaid, and their Succe≈ø≈øors for ever, ≈øo fully, freely, and wholly as in as ample manner and form as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents above mentioned, to be given or granted, or any other u≈øe, pre≈øcription, or any other Legal manner or Right what≈øoever before then re≈øpectively have been had, obtain'd or enjoy'd as if ≈øeparately, ≈øingly and name by name in, and by the ≈øaid Letters Patents of our ≈øaid King that now is, were, or have been expre≈ø≈øed, nominated, declared, granted and manife≈øted, as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents among other things more fully it doth, and may appear; And by that Authority, the ≈øaid Major and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London by the time in the Information afore≈øaid above ≈øpecified have been u≈øed and hitherto do u≈øe and claim to have, and u≈øe the Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchizes to be of them≈øelves one Body Corporate and Politick in Matter, Deed, and Name, by the Name of May or and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, and by that Name to Plead, and be Impleaded; to An≈øwer, and be An≈øwered; as to them it hath or may be Lawful.
Without that that the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London of the≈øe Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchizes upon our now Soveraign Lord the King by the time afore≈øaid in the Information above ≈øpecified have been U≈øurped, or do U≈øurp as by that Information for our ≈øaid Lord the King above it is ≈øuppo≈øed. Which all and ≈øingular the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London are ready to verifie, from whence they pray Judgment; And that the Liberties, Priviledges and Franchizes to them and their Succe≈ø≈øors for ever, ≈øhould be allowed and adjudged, and that they may be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, as al≈øo the Premi≈øes from this Court, &c. And the ≈øaid Mayor and Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London, ≈øo as their Liberties, Priviledges, and Franchizes following, viz. Them to have Sheriffs of the City and County of the City of London, and Sheriff of the County of Middle≈øex, and to Name, and Elect of them≈øelves their Per≈øons to be Sheriffs of the City afore≈øaid and County of the ≈øaid City, and Sheriff of Middle≈øex, and tho≈øe ≈øo Named and Elected to be made and con≈øtituted Sheriffs of the ≈øaid City and County of the ≈øaid City, and Sheriff of the ≈øaid County of Middle≈øex, and as Sheriff of the ≈øaid City & in the County of the ≈øaid City to execut & Retorne all Writs, Bills, and Precepts of our ≈øaid Lord the King for the Admini≈øtration and Execution of Ju≈øtice within the ≈øaid City, and County of the ≈øaid City, to perform and do what ≈øhall appertain or belong to the Office of Sheriff, and al≈øo to do and perform, and all and ≈øingular others within the ≈øaid City and County of the ≈øame, which ≈øhall appertain to, or belong to the Office of Sheriff, al≈øo to ≈øerve as
Sheriff for the County of Middle≈øex, and all Writs, Bills and Precepts of our Lord the King within the ≈øaid County of Middle≈øex, for the Admini≈øtration and Execution of Ju≈øtice there, to perform and make return thereof, which belongs or appertains to the Office of Sheriff: Say our ≈øaid Lord the King ought not to impeach or hinder them the Mayor, Commonalty and Citizens of the City of London by occa≈øion thereof, becau≈øe they ≈øay, that the City of London is and time out of mind hath been an ancient City and County of them≈øelves. And that the ≈øaid County of Middle≈øex, by the time afore≈øaid, hath been and is an ancient County. And that the Citizens of the ≈øaid City are and from which time, beyond the memory of Man, hath been one Body Corporate and Politick, not only by the Name of Mayor and Commonalty of the Citizens of the City of London, but al≈øo by the Names of the Citizens of London.
